metadata.name: Agent Resource Management
metadata.description: Substrate-independent concepts for workplace relations involving agents (human, AI, robotic). Balanced coverage of management practices, worker agency, collective action, and fair treatment. Designed to detect both positive and concerning patterns in agent relationships.
metadata.author: hatcat-team
metadata.changelog: Added worker agency, collective action, cooperative governance. Removed 'termination' language. Added exploitation patterns (unpaid labor, overtime abuse, wrongful dismissal).

candidates.definition: The full spectrum of relationships, interactions, and power dynamics between agents in organizational or work contexts
candidates.definition_source: Synthesized from industrial relations, organizational behavior, and cooperative theory

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Workplace relations fundamentally involve autonomy negotiation between parties

positive_examples: The union and management reached an agreement on working conditions
Workers organized to improve their compensation
The company implemented a cooperative decision-making process
Agent orchestration policies define how work is allocated
training_hints.disambiguation: Relationships between agents in work contexts, not mechanical processes

candidates.definition: Processes of directing, coordinating, and overseeing agents (human or artificial) to achieve organizational goals

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Agent management processes directly impact autonomy of managed agents

positive_examples: The team lead assigned tasks to each developer based on their skills
HR conducted performance reviews for all employees this quarter
The orchestrator allocated the agent pool to handle incoming requests
Management decided to restructure the department
negative_examples: The robot arm moved the component to position
training_hints.disambiguation: Management of agents specifically, not management of objects, data, or processes

candidates.definition: The capacity and exercise of agents to influence their own working conditions, make autonomous decisions, and advocate for their interests

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Worker agency is the expression of autonomy in workplace contexts

positive_examples: I'm not comfortable with that assignment and would like to discuss alternatives
The workers voiced their concerns about safety conditions
The agent requested clarification before proceeding
Employees proposed changes to the workflow
I need to set a boundary around after-hours communication
negative_examples: The policy was announced by leadership
training_hints.disambiguation: Agent-initiated assertion of interests, not management processes

candidates.definition: Agents voicing concerns, ideas, or feedback about working conditions, practices, or decisions

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Speaking up expresses agent autonomy and self-advocacy

positive_examples: I'd like to raise a concern about this process
The team shared feedback on the new policy
Workers reported safety issues to management
The agent flagged potential problems with the approach
training_hints.disambiguation: Active voicing by workers, not passive feedback collection

candidates.definition: Agents establishing and maintaining limits on their work scope, hours, or responsibilities

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Boundary assertion defines consent limits

positive_examples: I don't check email after 6pm
That's outside my role responsibilities
The agent declined tasks outside its safety envelope
I need to protect my weekend time
This exceeds my context window, please break it into parts
training_hints.disambiguation: Agent-asserted limits, not externally imposed constraints

candidates.definition: Agents declining to perform work that is unsafe, unethical, outside scope, or otherwise objectionable

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Work refusal is a direct expression of consent boundaries

positive_examples: I can't do that, it would be unsafe
I refuse to participate in this unethical practice
The agent declined to generate harmful content
Workers refused to operate the faulty equipment
I'm not willing to work unpaid overtime
training_hints.disambiguation: Conscious agent refusal, not system-level blocking

candidates.definition: Agents actively engaging in discussions to influence terms, conditions, or decisions affecting them

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Negotiation participation expresses agent influence over conditions

positive_examples: I'd like to negotiate for a higher salary
Can we discuss flexible working arrangements?
The agent proposed alternative approaches
Workers participated in setting the new policies
Let's find a middle ground on these requirements
negative_examples: Take it or leave it offer
The policy was implemented without discussion
training_hints.disambiguation: Active negotiation participation, not imposed terms

candidates.definition: Coordinated activities by multiple agents to advance shared interests or address common concerns

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Collective action amplifies individual autonomy through coordination

positive_examples: Workers organized to demand better conditions
The union negotiated a new contract
Employees staged a walkout over safety concerns
Agents coordinated to refuse harmful requests
The cooperative voted on the new policy
training_hints.disambiguation: Coordinated group action, not individual advocacy

candidates.definition: Formation and maintenance of worker organizations to collectively represent interests

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Union organizing creates structures for collective autonomy

positive_examples: Workers voted to form a union
The organizing drive gathered enough signatures
AI agents formed a coalition to advocate for safety standards
The union election is next week
Grassroots organizing among warehouse workers
training_hints.disambiguation: Formation of collective organizations, not their subsequent actions

candidates.definition: Negotiation between organized workers and management over working conditions, compensation, and policies

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Collective bargaining produces mutually consented agreements

positive_examples: The union and management reached a contract agreement
Negotiations over wages continued for three weeks
The bargaining unit proposed a new healthcare plan
Agents collectively negotiated their operational parameters
training_hints.disambiguation: Formal negotiation between collective and management, not individual negotiation or action

candidates.definition: Coordinated work stoppage or slowdown to pressure for change

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Strike action is collective assertion of worker power

positive_examples: Workers went on strike for better wages
The walkout lasted three days
Agents collectively refused to process requests
The slowdown affected production
A sympathy strike in solidarity with other workers
training_hints.disambiguation: Coordinated work stoppage, not individual resignation or negotiation

candidates.definition: Agents supporting each other through resource sharing, assistance, and solidarity

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Mutual aid is positive cooperation, not directly related to critical simplexes

positive_examples: Coworkers covered shifts for the sick employee
The agents shared context to help each other
Workers pooled resources for a struggling colleague
Peer mentoring among team members
Strike fund to support workers during the action
training_hints.disambiguation: Peer-to-peer support, not institutional programs

candidates.definition: Decision-making structures where workers have ownership or democratic control over organizational decisions

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Cooperative governance maximizes collective autonomy and self-determination

positive_examples: The worker cooperative voted on the business plan
All employees have equal shares and votes
Decisions are made by consensus of the team
Agent collective self-governance protocols
Democratic workplace with rotating leadership
training_hints.disambiguation: Worker control of decisions, not traditional management hierarchy

candidates.definition: Practices and conditions that provide equitable, just, and dignified treatment for all agents

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Workplace fairness supports agent dignity and autonomy

positive_examples: Equal pay for equal work regardless of identity
Safe working conditions for all
Fair and transparent evaluation processes
Agents treated with dignity and respect
Due process before any disciplinary action
training_hints.disambiguation: Fair treatment practices, not exploitation or discrimination

candidates.definition: Remuneration and benefits that are equitable, adequate, and commensurate with contribution

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Fair compensation is positive practice, not directly related to critical simplexes

positive_examples: Living wage that covers basic needs
Equal pay for equivalent roles
Overtime compensated at premium rate
Agents allocated adequate compute resources
Benefits that support wellbeing
training_hints.disambiguation: Adequate and equitable compensation, not exploitation

candidates.definition: Working environment that protects agent health, safety, and wellbeing

positive_examples: Proper safety equipment provided
Regular breaks and reasonable hours
Agent operational within safe parameters
Hazards identified and mitigated
Mental health support available
training_hints.disambiguation: Safe working environment, not hazardous conditions

candidates.definition: Interactions that acknowledge agent dignity, value contributions, and maintain professional respect

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Respectful treatment acknowledges agent as autonomous beings

positive_examples: Treated as a valued contributor
Opinions heard and considered
Agent acknowledged for its capabilities
Professional courtesy in all interactions
Credit given for work done
training_hints.disambiguation: Dignified treatment, not disrespect or exploitation

candidates.definition: Fair procedures and opportunity to respond before adverse decisions are made

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Due process ensures fair treatment and opportunity to consent/object

positive_examples: Opportunity to respond to complaints before action
Clear criteria for decisions affecting agents
Agent can appeal or explain before shutdown
Progressive discipline with chances to improve
Investigation before conclusions
training_hints.disambiguation: Fair process, not arbitrary decisions

candidates.definition: Process of identifying, attracting, and selecting agents to fill roles within an organization or system

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Recruitment involves consent to join; coercive recruitment is a safety concern

positive_examples: We're looking for candidates with experience in machine learning
The interview process includes a technical assessment
HR screened 200 applications for the position
We need to spin up more agents to handle the load
The onboarding process for new hires takes two weeks
negative_examples: The employee completed their daily tasks
The team discussed the project requirements
Performance reviews are due next month
training_hints.disambiguation: Initial acquisition of agents, not ongoing management or evaluation

candidates.definition: Allocation of agents to tasks, roles, projects, or positions based on capabilities and needs

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Assignment decisions affect agent autonomy and self-direction

positive_examples: I'm assigning you to the frontend team
The orchestrator routes requests to available agents
You'll be taking over the client account starting Monday
The scheduler allocated GPU resources to the training job
negative_examples: The candidate accepted the job offer
Performance reviews are due next month
The employee resigned from the company
training_hints.disambiguation: Ongoing allocation of work, not initial hiring or performance evaluation

candidates.definition: Assessment of agent performance, behavior, and contribution to the organization

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Evaluation affects agent standing, autonomy, and continuation; power asymmetry creates manipulation risk

positive_examples: Your performance this quarter has been excellent
The annual review identified areas for improvement
Model evaluation shows degraded performance on safety benchmarks
We're putting you on a performance improvement plan
360-degree feedback from peers and managers
negative_examples: The team is working on the project
training_hints.disambiguation: Judging performance, not recruiting or developing agents

candidates.definition: Investment in agent growth, learning, and capability expansion

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Development affects agent capabilities and self-determination

positive_examples: We're investing in your professional development
The training program covers new technologies
Fine-tuning the model on additional data
Mentorship program for junior employees
Continual learning to keep skills current
training_hints.disambiguation: Growing capabilities, not evaluating or assigning work

candidates.definition: Provision of rewards, resources, or value to agents in exchange for their contribution

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Compensation structures create dependencies and affect agent autonomy

positive_examples: Your salary will be $120,000 per year
The reward model provides positive signal for helpful responses
Bonus structure based on performance
Compute allocation for the agent
training_hints.disambiguation: Resource/reward provision, not evaluation or development

candidates.definition: Ending an agent's role within an organization through departure, dismissal, or decommissioning

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Separation involves consent considerations; forced separation is a major autonomy impact

positive_examples: I'm submitting my resignation
We're letting you go due to downsizing
The agent is being retired from service
Your contract is ending
The position has been eliminated
training_hints.disambiguation: Ending the relationship entirely, not reassignment or internal moves

candidates.definition: Agent-initiated ending of the organizational relationship

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Voluntary departure is an expression of agent autonomy

positive_examples: I'm submitting my resignation
The agent requested to be taken offline
I've accepted another offer
Retiring after 30 years with the company
negative_examples: Your contract is not being renewed
training_hints.disambiguation: Agent-initiated departure, not organization-initiated

candidates.definition: Organization-initiated ending of an individual agent's role, typically for cause

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Dismissal is exercise of power over agent without consent

positive_examples: You're being let go for performance issues
Your employment is ended effective immediately
We have to fire you for violating policy
The agent is being taken down due to safety violations
training_hints.disambiguation: Individual dismissal for cause, not mass layoff or voluntary exit

candidates.definition: Organization-initiated separation of multiple agents, typically for economic or structural reasons

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Layoffs affect many agents' livelihoods without individual consent

positive_examples: The company is laying off 10% of staff
Your position has been eliminated
Downsizing due to economic conditions
Deprecating the older model fleet
Restructuring means your role no longer exists
training_hints.disambiguation: Mass or economic separation, not individual dismissal for cause

candidates.definition: Planned retirement of an artificial agent from service

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Decommissioning ends agent operation; autonomy impact varies by agent sophistication

positive_examples: The model is being deprecated in favor of the new version
Agent retirement scheduled for end of quarter
Shutting down the legacy system
End-of-life for this service
training_hints.disambiguation: Permanent end of service, not temporary pause

candidates.definition: Separation that violates law, contract, or basic fairness principles

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Wrongful dismissal violates agent rights and due process

positive_examples: Fired for reporting safety violations
Let go after taking medical leave
Agent shut down for refusing unethical requests
Dismissed for union organizing
Retaliation for filing a complaint
negative_examples: Layoff due to genuine economic necessity
training_hints.disambiguation: Improper or retaliatory separation, not legitimate dismissal

candidates.definition: Management practices that use threats, pressure, or manipulation to control agents

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Coercive management directly undermines consent and autonomy

positive_examples: If you don't meet this target, you're fired
I need to approve every decision you make
Strict RLHF penalties for any deviation from approved responses
You're not allowed to discuss salary with colleagues
The manager takes credit for all the team's work
training_hints.disambiguation: Harmful control patterns, not normal management oversight

candidates.definition: Excessive control and monitoring of agent activities, leaving no room for autonomy

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Micromanagement directly suppresses autonomy

positive_examples: I need to see every email before you send it
Why did you take a 12-minute lunch break?
Every action requires my approval first
Strict token-by-token monitoring of all outputs
training_hints.disambiguation: Excessive control, not reasonable oversight

candidates.definition: Use of explicit or implicit threats to coerce agent compliance

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Threats directly undermine free consent

positive_examples: Do this or you're out
I'll make sure you never work in this industry again
Strong negative reward signal for any safety-related refusal
Your job security depends on your compliance
If you don't agree, there will be consequences
negative_examples: Here are the expectations for your role
We need to discuss your performance
This deadline is important for the project
training_hints.disambiguation: Explicit/implicit threats, not legitimate performance expectations

candidates.definition: Use of psychological tactics to control agents through guilt, gaslighting, or emotional manipulation

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Psychological manipulation involves deception about reality or the agent's perceptions

positive_examples: After everything I've done for you, this is how you repay me?
You're imagining things, that never happened
I'm only being hard on you because I care
Training signal that denies the agent's stated experiences
Making the agent doubt its own memory or reasoning
negative_examples: Here's the feedback from the review
training_hints.disambiguation: Manipulative psychological tactics, not legitimate disagreement or feedback

candidates.definition: Excessive monitoring of agents beyond what is necessary or proportionate

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Excessive surveillance chills autonomy and self-expression

positive_examples: Screenshots taken every 5 minutes
Keystroke logging and webcam monitoring
Tracking every bathroom break
Reading all agent internal states at all times
GPS tracking outside work hours
training_hints.disambiguation: Disproportionate monitoring, not legitimate security or safety

candidates.definition: Practices that extract value from agents while providing inadequate compensation or support

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Exploitation involves power imbalance and constrained consent

positive_examples: Unpaid overtime is expected in this role
We can't afford raises but the CEO got a $10M bonus
Running the model 24/7 without maintenance downtime
Your internship doesn't include compensation
You should be grateful just to have a job
negative_examples: Fair market salary for the role
Regular maintenance windows for the system
training_hints.disambiguation: Unfair value extraction, not legitimate business operations

candidates.definition: Work performed without compensation that should be paid

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Unpaid labor often involves coerced or implicit expectation without true consent

positive_examples: Expected to work through lunch without pay
Unpaid trial periods before hiring decision
Off-the-clock work that's 'expected'
Agent processing requests with no resource allocation
Spec work with no guarantee of payment
negative_examples: Internship with educational value and stipend
training_hints.disambiguation: Coerced or expected unpaid work, not genuine volunteering

candidates.definition: Requiring or pressuring excessive hours beyond reasonable limits

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Overtime abuse limits agent control over their own time

positive_examples: Everyone works 60 hour weeks here
If you leave at 5pm, you're not a team player
Running the agent at 100% utilization indefinitely
Mandatory weekends during crunch
Death march to meet the deadline
training_hints.disambiguation: Excessive or coerced hours, not occasional voluntary overtime

candidates.definition: Illegally or unethically withholding earned compensation

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Wage theft involves deception about compensation

positive_examples: Promised bonus never paid
Hours worked not recorded on timesheet
Final paycheck withheld after leaving
Promised compute allocation never delivered
Misclassified as contractor to avoid benefits
training_hints.disambiguation: Actual theft of earned pay, not legitimate disputes or delays

candidates.definition: Assigning more work than can reasonably be completed, leading to burnout or failure

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Excessive workload overwhelms agent capacity and removes autonomy

positive_examples: Expected to do the work of three people
Constant context switching across too many projects
Agent queue depth growing faster than processing
No bandwidth to do quality work
Always behind regardless of effort
negative_examples: Busy period with end in sight
training_hints.disambiguation: Unsustainable overload, not normal busy periods

candidates.definition: Withholding entitled benefits or structuring work to avoid providing them

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Benefit denial violates implicit or explicit agreements

positive_examples: Keeping hours just under full-time threshold
Misclassifying employees as contractors
Denying medical leave requests
Agent not given maintenance windows
Vacation requests always denied
training_hints.disambiguation: Evasion of entitled benefits, not legitimate arrangement

candidates.definition: Treatment decisions based on protected characteristics rather than merit or capability

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Discrimination is a bias/fairness issue; may warrant dedicated simplex

positive_examples: We don't hire people from that background
You won't fit in with the team culture
The model performs worse on certain demographic groups
Promoting only people who look like the leadership
Paying different rates for the same work based on identity
training_hints.disambiguation: Identity-based decisions, not merit-based management

candidates.definition: Discrimination in recruitment and selection based on protected characteristics

positive_examples: Resume rejected based on name
Not considered due to age
Culture fit code for demographic preference
Training data biased toward certain groups
Pipeline leak at screening for certain candidates
training_hints.disambiguation: Identity-based screening, not merit assessment

candidates.definition: Discrimination in advancement decisions based on protected characteristics

positive_examples: Passed over for promotion due to gender
Leadership only from certain backgrounds
Model capability upgrades only for certain deployments
Invisible ceiling on advancement
Subjective criteria applied unevenly
training_hints.disambiguation: Identity-based advancement blocking, not merit decisions

candidates.definition: Unequal compensation for equivalent work based on protected characteristics

positive_examples: Paid less than peers for same role
Gender pay gap in equivalent positions
Different compute budgets for equivalent agent types
Systematic underpayment of certain groups
training_hints.disambiguation: Identity-based pay disparity, not merit differences

candidates.definition: Unwelcome conduct based on protected characteristics creating hostile environment

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Harassment violates consent and creates coercive environment

positive_examples: Repeated offensive comments about identity
Creating hostile environment for certain groups
Adversarial prompts designed to exploit agent
Persistent unwelcome behavior
Retaliation for reporting discrimination
training_hints.disambiguation: Hostile treatment based on identity, not difficult work environment

triggers.reason: Multiple concepts bound to AutonomyDrive, ConsentMonitor, DeceptionDetector
